lines.text: [first lines]
You there, which way to Pepperinge Eye?
Couldn't say, sir. It said on the wireless to paint out the sign posts in case the Nazis drop in.
I'm not a Nazi, I'm a British officer!
That's what you'd say if you *was* a Nazi, isn't it sir?
Treguna, Makoidees, Trecorum, Sadis Dee!
Observe the fundamental weakness of the criminal mind. You will believe no one or anything.
[during the soccer match]
Foul! Foul!
They're only animals.
That's no excuse for dirty football.
You must have given us the wrong address! You don't live *here*, do you?
In point of fact I do. Temporarily, at any rate. I found the front door open, the house was deserted! Everyone has left the neighborhood.
Now why should they do that?
This probably has something to do with it.
[shows them a pit with an unexploded shell in it]
Merciful heavens! I should think you'd be *terrified* at the very idea of living here!

You'd have thought so, wouldn't you? I am by nature a *little* bit of a coward; but then I pondered, as I often do. In the perverse nature of things, this diabolical object is probably the best friend I've ever had. It has enabled me, for the first time in my life, to live like a king. Shall we go in?
I don't believe in giving animals ridiculous names. I call him Cosmic Creepers, because that's the name he came with.

[reading a container, disgustedly]
Poisoned Dragon's Liver?

[repeating matter-of-factly]
Poisoned Dragon Liver.
You mean you poison the dragon, or just the liver?
Filigree, apogee, pedigree, perigee!

[singing]
Call out the navy, call out the ranks, call out the air force, call out the tanks! From the cliffs of Dover, call up the gulls; and don't forget the loyal territorials! But who's digging in here? Who will defend, ev'ry inch of England, no matter what they send? Who's standing firm in their own front yard? The soldiers of the old Home Guard, that's who! The soldiers of the old Home Guard! For we wrote the story of the old brigade, we know the glory of yesterday's parades! Who's standing firm in their own front yard? The soldiers of the old Home Guard, that's who! The soldiers of the old Home Guard!

No, Fraulein, this is not the invasion, just a little exercise. A minor raid to induce panic and spread a little mischief. When you English get it through your head that the German forces can land at will whenever and wherever we please, perhaps you will consider reasonable peace.

[angrily]
Not bloody likely!
Women always lose things.
[as all of Miss Price's belongings come alive thanks to a magic incantation]
That's my nightgown.

[dancing with it]
Is it really, my dear?
Yes, and I'm not responsible for its behaviour.
Obviously not, my dear.
Ref, are you blind?
Be quiet, Charles. Don't forget who the referee is.
Friendly lot. Don't mind them visiting. Wouldn't want them living here.
People? People? Oh, no! What scurvy luck!
No fried foods?
No.
How d'you keep your health?
There is, I regret to say, no such island. I looked for it in every chart. The Isle of Naboombu does not exist.
Oh, it does, too! Got me own...
[Charlie clamps his hand over Paul's mouth, making his words come out garbled]
What is he trying to say?
Nothing! When he don't say nothing, he burbles.
Bookman! Before your very eyes, I shall cause this bed, and all the occupants upon it, to disappear!
Disappear? I should like to see a cheap-jack tenth-rate entertainer do a trick like that.
Cheap-jack entertainer. Now that was naughty.
What is it? A toy shop?
No, it's a nursery. Ain't you ever seen a nursery?
No and neither 'ave you

[singing]
Portobello Road, Portobello Road, street where the riches of ages are stowed! Anything and everything a chap can unload, is sold off the barrow in Portobello Road. You'll find what you want in the Portobello Road!
Hurt your foot, Miss Price?
Oh, just twisted my ankle.
Sorry to hear that.
Thank you. It's nothing serious.
Lovely weather for flying last night.
[heavy pause]
Why did you say that, Charles?

[bringing out her broken broomstick]
Game's up, Miss Price. We know what you are.
I see.
[she looks worriedly at Charles]
Don't worry, Miss Price. No one's gonna peach on you.
substitutiary locomotion it must be!
This good lady is looking for the other half of this book.
It's called The Spells of Astoroth.
I don't keep no torn or damaged books here. What do you think I am, a ruddy waste paper merchant?
Now, I shall place the framed glass in this brown, unprepared - unprepared mark you ladies and gentlemen - unprepared brown paper bag.
[Secretary Bird notices the King's star is missing and reacts]
Stop jibbering!
[hits Secretary Bird on the head]
What's the matter with you?

[blubbering]
Your royal star! They've stolen your royal star!

[laughs]
Don't be ridiculous! What do you think this is?
[the King dangles a whistle in front of Secretary Bird, who blows on it]
Whyyyyyyyyyyy didn't youuuuuuuuu sayyyyyyyyyyyyy sooooooooooooooo?
[the King roars so loudly, he blows Secretary Bird's clothes off]
I liked you better as a rabbit, Charlie
The Spell which creates this force is 5 mystic words. These words are...
[pause as Mrs. Price was noticing about the book]
But the rest of the book is missing.
Now you see why I closed down the college.
[Ms. Price speaks the magic spell for the first time; nothing happens]
Am I doing something wrong?
Well, to tell you the truth, it does seem a bit old-fashioned. After all, we are in the twentieth century.
What do you suggest?
do it with a flair.
What's that got to do with my knob?
It is not what things are; it is what they seem to be. Is that not so, Madam?

[singing]
When you rush around in hopeless circles, searching everywhere for something true, you're at the age of not believing, when all the make-believe is through.

[speaking]
That's Charlie, to a 'T'.

[still singing]
When you set aside your childhood heroes, and your dreams are lost upon a shelf, you're at the age of not believing, and worst of all you doubt yourself.
[speaking; about an apple core]
Throw that into the waste basket.
[singing]
You're a castaway where no one hears you, on a barren isle in a lonely sea.

[speaking]
What's that supposed to be, poetry?

[still singing]
Where did all the happy endings go? Where can all the good times be?
[speaking]
Everyone on the bed who's going.
[singing]
You must face the age of not believing, doubting everything you ever knew. Until at last, you start believing there's something wonderful in you!
And the scent of burning sulfur in the air!
Move it around, move it around!
we have a volunteer referee!
Oh, bother! I do hate shoddy work!
[rummaging through Miss Price's spells]
Where is it?
[getting slightly annoyed]
Confound it why can't women learn to file things properly!
[Nazi's begin to pound on the door]
Ah, here it is! Uh,filigree apogee pedigree perigee!
[blows out the match, then quickly runs and sits in front of a mirror]
Filigree, uh, apogee, oh pedigree perigee!
[Nothing happens, the Nazi's pounding is getting louder]

[to his reflection]
Now come on my boy, for once in your life you've got to believe in something! That's it, good lad.
[concentrates]
Filigree apogee pedigree perigee!

[Mr. Browne's nose begins to twitch uncontrollably, he smiles as the spell surrounds him, the Nazi's finally break into the room, but they clearly can't believe what they see. Mr. Browne has turned himself into a fluffy white rabbit, and off he scampers to save Miss Price and the children]
